Expectation1: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation1: A mandatory pre-shift briefing on new operational procedures is about to start.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: I glance at the clock in the break room, heart pounding. The mandatory pre-shift briefing on the new operational procedures is about to start, and as a subway operator, I know I can’t miss it. Management has been clear: attendance is non-negotiable, and these updates are crucial for passenger safety. But my mind keeps drifting to the envelope of tax documents I’ve organized at home. As a citizen, I pride myself on being responsible—filing early, following every guideline, doing my part. And this weekend, the community center is hosting a free vaccine clinic. I’ve been meaning to volunteer, to help neighbors who can’t get there on their own. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in. My job demands my full attention and presence, but my sense of civic duty tugs at me, reminding me that being a good citizen means more than just showing up for work. I stand in the hallway, torn, the expectations of both worlds swirling inside me, unsure which responsibility should come first.
